k_seq.utility.file_tools.check_dir(path)¶

Check if a path exists, create if not

k_seq.utility.file_tools.dump_pickle(obj, path)¶
k_seq.utility.file_tools.extract_metadata(target, pattern)¶

Function to extract metadata info from target given pattern todo: update method to account for missing metadata situation. e.g. matching -A- to -{d1}{d2}- :param target: string to extract info from, e.g. sample file name :type target: str :param pattern: string indicate the method to extract metadata. Use [...] to include the region of sample_name,

use {domain_name[, int/float]} to indicate region of domain to extract as metadata, including [,int/float] will convert the domain value to float in applicable, otherwise, string

Returns

dictionary of all metadata extracted from domains indicated in pattern

Return type

dict

Example

Example on metadata extraction from pattern:

>>> extract_metadata(
        sample_name = "R4B-1250A_S16_counts.txt"
        pattern = "R4[{exp_rep}-{concentration, float}{seq_rep}_S{id, int}]_counts.txt"
    )
metadata = {
    'name': 'B-1250A_S16',
    'exp_rep': 'B',
    'concentration': 1250.0,
    'seq_rep': 'A',
    'id': 16
    }
k_seq.utility.file_tools.get_file_list(file_root, pattern=None, file_list=None, black_list=None, full_path=True)¶

list all files under the given file root(s) follows the pattern if given, folders are not included

Parameters

  • file_root (str of list of str) – root directory or a list of root directory

  • pattern (str) – optional, include all the files under directories if None

  • file_list (list of str) – optional, only includes the files with names in the file_list

  • black_list (list of str) – optional, file name include substring in black list will be excluded

  • full_path (bool) – if return the full path or only name of the file, by default, if file_root is one string, only file name will be returned; if file_root contains multiple strings, full path will be returned

Returns

list of file names/full directory

Return type

list of str or path.Path

A name scope for a group of attributes

Create a name scope for a group of attributes

Parameters

  • attr_dict (dict) – a dictionary with values to pass

  • keys (list of str) – a list of attributes to initialize with None

  • attr_kwargs – or directly pass some keyword arguments

class k_seq.utility.func_tools.DocHelper(**kwargs)¶

Bases: object

Helper for docstring controls in a module

var_lib¶

contains all documented variables, include columns of name (index), dtype, doc

Type

pd.DataFrame

add()¶

add keyword arguments to the doc_helper

get()¶

generate a formatted docstring

__init__(**kwargs)¶

Add arguments in initialization by keyword arguments Accept two values for kwargs:

  • str: the documentation string

  • tuple of (str, str): (variable type, docstring)

Examples

doc_strings = DocHelper(x=’the first integer’, y=(‘int’, ‘the second value’))

add(**kwargs)

Add kwarg arguments to the doc helper var_lib

get(var_names, indent=4, sep='')

Generate a formatted docstring

Args:

var_names (list, tuple, callable): a list or tuple of variable names to retrieve, if the variable name does

not exist in record, a line with null info will be created

indent (int): indent for the docstring lines. Default 4

sep (str): separation symbols between docstring lines (in addition of a natural line break). Default `

`

k_seq.utility.func_tools.get_func_params(func, exclude_x=True)¶

Utility function to get the number of arguments for a function (callable) :param func: the function :type func: callable :param exclude_x: if exclude the first argument (usually x) :type exclude_x: bool

Returns: a tuple of arguments name in order

k_seq.utility.func_tools.get_object_hex(obj)¶
k_seq.utility.func_tools.param_to_dict(key_list, **kwargs)¶

Assign kwargs to the dictionary with key from key_list - if the arg is a single value, it will be assigned to all keys - if the arg is a list, it will should have same length as key_list - if the arg is a dict, it should contain all members in the key

k_seq.utility.func_tools.update_none(arg, update_by)¶
